title: Chambi National Park
text:
Chambi National Park (sometimes Chambi Mountain National Park or Djebel Chambi National Park) is a <a href="national%20park">national park</a> in <a href="Tunisia">Tunisia</a>'s <a href="Kasserine%20Governorate">Kasserine Governorate</a>. It protects the flora and fauna surrounding <a href="Jebel%20ech%20Chambi">Mount Chambi</a> ("Djebel Chambi"), the highest mountain peak (1,544m above sea level) in Tunisia.
The park is part of the Mont de Tebessa forest massif which spans the area from Kasserine to the Algerian border. The parks has no permanent rivers or streams, but it is one of the last refuges of the endangered <a href="Cuvier%27s%20gazelle">Cuvier's gazelle</a> and home to vulnerable <a href="Barbary%20sheep">Barbary sheep</a>. The park is also the site of notable plant life (<a href="Quercus%20rotundifolia">holm oak</a> and <a href="Cotoneaster">Cotoneaster</a> nummularia, <a href="Aleppo%20pine">Aleppo pine</a>, and <a href="Stipa%20tenacissima">Stipa tenacissima</a>) and birds (including the Tunisian <a href="crossbill">crossbill</a>, the <a href="Egyptian%20vulture">Egyptian vulture</a>, <a href="Bonelli%27s%20eagle">Bonelli's eagle</a>, and the <a href="peregrine%20falcon">peregrine falcon</a>, among others).
In 1970, a fenced reserve was established to protect <a href="Cuvier%27s%20gazelle">Cuvier's gazelle</a>. In 1977, the park and its surrounding areas were designated a <a href="UNESCO%20biosphere%20reserve">UNESCO biosphere reserve</a>. The park was established as a national park in 1980.
